Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Situation2: The weekly group meditation meets for an hour today.
Story:
The phone buzzed insistently on my nightstand, jolting me from the quiet anticipation of my weekly meditation. I glanced at the clock—ten minutes before I was supposed to join the group. My friend’s name flashed on the screen, and when I answered, her voice was raw with tears. She could barely speak, her words tumbling out between sobs about her family’s sudden tragedy. I felt her pain through the line, every instinct urging me to stay, to listen, to be the friend she needed right now.

But in the back of my mind, the gentle pull of my Buddhist practice called to me. The group would be gathering soon, sitting together in silence, breathing in unison, cultivating the mindfulness I’d promised myself to nurture. I knew how much I needed that hour of stillness, how it grounded me and helped me be present for others. Yet here I was, torn—my friend’s grief anchoring me to the moment, my commitment to meditation urging me to let go. My heart ached with the weight of both roles, unsure which path to follow.
